scenario: A colleague proposes a bold idea that might fail but could have huge upside.

options.text: Encourage them and explore the idea further.
Start evaluating feasibility immediately.
Push to test it quickly despite risks.

scenario: You are working on a long-term project and hit a slow, boring phase.

options.text: Remind yourself why the work matters.
Seek help from teammates to maintain progress.
Re-evaluate the commercial value to re-energize yourself.

scenario: Your team disagrees on a strategic direction.

options.text: Facilitate discussion to align the team.
Look at market data to decide.
Experiment with both paths briefly.

scenario: You discover a new technology relevant to your field.

options.text: Explore its potential applications deeply.
Prototype something quickly using it.
Pitch a bold concept using the technology.

scenario: You receive difficult feedback about your project.

options.text: Reflect and adjust your strategy calmly.
Seek input from others to improve it.
Validate assumptions again with customers.

scenario: You need to choose between a safe project and a highly innovative one.

options.text: Pick the innovative project — bigger upside.
Pick the safe one — more reliable path.
Pick the one that aligns with your long-term purpose.

scenario: Your team is stuck on a problem.

options.text: Generate fresh creative angles.
Break problem into executable tasks.
Reframe it from the customer’s perspective.

scenario: You must deliver a project but time is limited.

options.text: Motivate the team to push through.
Take leadership and coordinate people tightly.
Simplify the scope and execute fast.

scenario: You're asked to present an idea to senior stakeholders.

options.text: Focus on big-picture concepts and vision.
Focus on feasibility and actionable steps.
Focus on market need and value proposition.

scenario: A new opportunity appears, but resources are limited.

options.text: Take the risk — resource issues can be solved later.
Prioritise based on strategic fit and value.
Stick to the original plan and avoid distractions.
